response.original_title: Somebody was Trying to Kill Somebody Else
response.overview: "Part of an ongoing project called Scanning Cinema [that consists] of scanning moving images by using a flatbed scanner and a monitor and putting them back into an animated film. The inversions [produced by this] method (the physical action of scanning) [generate] a new language like a disturbed echo from the photographic reviving of moving images. […] The fragments … used [here] are a re-montage of Michelangelo Antonioni’s Blow-Up, [while] the original soundtrack of Herbie Hancock has undergone the same process as the images. The movie consists of 10,000 scans put together in a stop-motion film." (Benjamin Verhoeven)
response.title: Somebody was Trying to Kill Somebody Else

release_dates.note: Expanding Bauhaus. New Reflections on the Bauhaus Movement in Time-Based Media Art / Goethe Institute Netherlands
Paradox in Language: What I look at is never what I wish to see
